lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I wonder where we are now?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Well, you're somewhere near a town now called Manhattan Kansas.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: But this particular spot is actually a cryptomine...

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: cryptomine?

lines.speaker: ITG
lines.text: *beeps*

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: You might want to ask your Internet Travel Guide more about that.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: I know my way around a server, but crypto – I don't truck with that nonsense.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: how did you know we had a guide?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: How do you think I found you?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Cryptomining is a practice used to decentralize transaction information for cryptocurrencies.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Cryptominers use computers with high processing power to solve complex number comparisons through brute force.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: They're essentially trying to guess a number lower than some unknown target number, but that unknown target number is getting added with *another* number that they also don't know.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Since the only way to guess correctly, they just keep guessing... trillions of times.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: As you can imagine, this uses a lot of energy!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: no breathers, I guess.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: we've heard a lot about that today, but I'll bite – how much energy?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The energy consumption for Bitcoin, the first and largest cryptocurrency, uses about 102.04 TWh per year, which is approximately 0.47% percent of the world's total energy consumption.

settings.text: click here for more resources on Bitcoin and energy use!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Which is more power than the Phillippines use – per *year!*

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: And as the value of these currencies increase in perceived value, Bitcoin self-balances by making the size in bits of the target number bigger, which exponentially increases the number of calculations required to guess it correctly.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: So the amount of time and energy needed to mine increases, even as the amount of currency mined stays the same.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: And it's still entirely random whether your trillions of calcuations result in currency, since a new coin is only given to the first miner that gets a correct hash.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Often, the value of the coin minted barely covers the energy costs of operating the mining rig!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: wow, so this entire system is a bit of nightmare... it's almost like this was designed to tear up the environment...

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: From the a miner's perspective, the best way to remain competitive and increase returns on investment is by increasing computing power.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: This competitive framework leads to more demand for high-powered computers and the strain on the computers means they will fall defunct sooner.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: This is how cryptomining leads to massive amounts of e-waste generated annually, just like your TV friend you met in the ocean.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The same thing happens with servers. To keep pace with the world's connectivity needs, a data center has to keep upgrading servers, hard drives, routers... and a *lot* of that winds up as e-waste!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: wow, that's pretty messed up!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: it's one thing for servers to use energy, I get that, but it feels weird that it's just a bunch of random people with huge computers churning through energy as fast as possible.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: and isn't this related to some big conversations going on throughout the art world at the moment when it comes to NFTs, whatever those are?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Hey, yeah! There's some of that going on too, over here!
